item.title: basic networking
item.description: OSI Layers(Open Systems Interconnection) and associated Protocol Data Unit(PDU) OSI Model is a 7 abstract layer table that’s responsible for explaining the flow of data within a network. Experienced individuals will often call out an issue by the culprit layer number. example: “This is a level 3 issue.” Protocol data unit(PDU) is a name given to the data when passing through each OSI layer. Bits, Frames, etc Physical - Layer 1 - Bits (PDU) Bit-by-bit delivery, modulation, start-stop signals, physical network.
item.dc:creator: Matt Raupfer

item.title: pending-navigating the linux filesystem
item.description: Explained: Terminal(emulator), shell, command-line(prompt) The most effective way, and arguably the only way, of navigating and managing a linux system is through the linux terminal. The linux terminal is the enviroment that provides the user interaction to the system via the shell. Shells are little programs, that come in various flavors, which processes the interaction between the user and system. Examples: BASH, zsh, SH, csh, ksh… etc A command-line is where your cursor sits and where you type.
item.dc:creator: Matt Raupfer

item.title: linux filesystem hierarchy
item.description: Linux uses a tree oriented hierarchy, meaning it starts at one point and branches outward. This starting point is the / (system root) directory. This particular hierarchy layout is based on the FHS (Filesystem Hierarchy Standard). FHS - (Filesystem Hierarchy Standard) Maintained by the Linux Foundation and last updated on June 3rd, 2015.(as of 12-16-22) FHS provides UNIX-like operating systems with a set of file and directory requirements and guidelines.
item.dc:creator: Matt Raupfer
